bibl.title: Letter from E.J. Scannell to Henry Rose Carter, June 3, 1923

div1.p: Scannell discusses sections from Carter's book, entitled "Epidemiology of Yellow Fever," and requests Carter's opinion on certain aspects.

div1.head: Letter from E.J. Scannell to Henry Rose Carter, June 3, 1923
div1.opener:
Book
Epidenity
Re Leptospira icteroides
p. 5
Show Jack.
PODER EJECUTIVO FEDERAL
MEXICO
DEPARTAMENTO
DE
SALUBRIDAD PUBLICA
-----
COMISION ESPECIAL PARA LA CAMPAÑA
CONTRA LA FIEBRE AMARILLA
-----
PRIMERA ZONA
-----
TAMPICO, TAMAULIPAS
Tampico,
Tams.
June 3, 1923.
Dear Doctor Carter;
div1.p:
I wish to tell you I have just received
a copy of your “Epidemiology of Yellow
Fever” and that I have been over it pretty
carefully. It is certainly thorough and
brings out many good points. I am certainly
thankful to have a copy.

You mention as regards the life of the female
Aedes that she may live many months but is it
not a fact she seldom lives longer than 25 to
30 days under natural conditions? I know
that in homes where they have been quite a
nuisance after three to four weeks work
eliminating breeding places it is difficult
to find adults.

You also mention they do not breed in deposits
with exclusively earth sides - that has been my
experience but I find they do breed in deposits
with solid wood ash sides. In certain places
in this area the people build up mounds of
wood ashes on the ground, make a hollow in
the center and fill this with water - in this
the stegs breed profusely.

As regards the temperature of election for
the production and activity of Aedes you
give us definite maxima and minima but would
you mind telling me why the biology of the
Leptospira should not also be considered?
The organism is very sensitive to temperature
PODER EJECUTIVO FEDERAL
MEXICO
DEPARTAMENTO
DE
SALUBRIDAD PUBLICA
-----
COMISION ESPECIAL PARA LA CAMPAÑA
CONTRA LA FIEBRE AMARILLA
-----
PRIMERA ZONA
-----
TAMPICO, TAMAULIPAS
NO.__________
2.
and I think Doctor Noguchi told me it was
necessary to maintain a constant temperature
of 80 degrees F. in the incubator in order
for them to properly develop and multiply.
A drop of a few degrees was fatal to them
if I remember correctly.

If the above is true why shouldnt the
temperature changes which we have in certain
places, Tampico as an example, where the drop
is terrific at times especially during the
norther season be a very important factor
considering the organism alone? Here although
we have severe drops in temperature the drop
is very temporary and the stegs can readily
survive insides the houses.

It has seemed to me that the changes of
temperature as affecting the viability of
the Leptospira is as important, possibly
more so than any effect it might have on the
Aedes. I am referring to the Leptospira in the
mosquito - in the human with a temperature
more or less constant 98.3 naturally the case
would be somewhat different.

I have never had the pleasure of getting your
views as regards the organism itself.
If you have time would you please give me
your viewpoint regarding above?

Please commend me to Miss Carter. I trust this
finds you in your usual good health.
div1.closer:
Very respectfully yours, E. J. Scannell Doctor H. R. Carter,
Assistant Surgeon General, U. S. P. H. Service.
